Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: Assisting at a traffic accident scene to ensure safety and order
Story: The radio crackled as I directed traffic around the accident, my mind only half on the job. My phone buzzed in my pocket—my stepbrother, Jamie, again. He’d been texting all morning about trying a new skateboard trick on the old, crumbling ramp behind our house. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But as a police officer, I couldn’t just abandon my post at the accident scene; people were counting on me to keep the intersection safe, to prevent another crash. I could picture Jamie, helmet askew, grinning as he eyed the ramp’s jagged edge. My heart pounded with worry—what if he got hurt while I was here, doing my duty? I felt torn in two, the weight of both uniforms—family and law—pressing down on me, each demanding I be somewhere else, someone else, at the very same moment.
